A patient may have two types of primary [[Headache SD-118|headache]] intertwined, most commonly a migraine without aura and an episodic tension headache.

In the case of CCQ (> 15 days per month of headaches), if the patient has migraines and tension headaches, the diagnosis of migraine takes precedence, and a chronic migraine must be diagnosed as soon as there are 8 days per month (2 days per week) of headache of a migrainous nature.

question.title: When to prioritize migraines over tension headaches
question.description: A patient may have two types of primary headache disorders intertwined, most commonly a migraine without aura and an episodic tension headache. In the case of chronic headaches (CCQ > 15 days per month of headaches), if the patient has migraines and tension headaches, the diagnosis of migraine takes precedence, and a chronic migraine must be diagnosed as soon as there are 8 days per month (2 days per week) of headache of a migrainous nature.

option_a.title: A patient with migraines and tension headaches should be diagnosed with tension headaches first.
option_a.description: This is because tension headaches are more common and have a higher prevalence than migraines.

option_b.title: A patient with migraines and tension headaches should be diagnosed with migraines first.
option_b.description: This is because migraines are more severe and have a higher impact on quality of life than tension headaches.

option_c.title: The diagnosis of migraines takes precedence over tension headaches in cases of chronic headaches.
option_c.description: This is because migraines are more likely to be chronic and require long-term management.

option_d.title: A patient with migraines and tension headaches should be diagnosed with tension headaches first.
option_d.description: This is because tension headaches are more common and have a higher prevalence than migraines.

correct_option.title: A patient with migraines and tension headaches should be diagnosed with migraines first.
correct_option.description: This is because migraines are more severe and have a higher impact on quality of life than tension headaches.
